title: Apostle Islands National Lakeshore: Planning
body: Explore This Park    Get Involved     Planning             Planning          General Management Plan This approved General Management Plan/Wilderness Management Plan (2011) will be the basic document the National Park Service (NPS) intends to follow in managing the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore over the next 15–20 years.            Wilderness Study The purpose of the Wilderness Study (2004) was to develop a proposal to the Director of the National Park Service, the Secretary of Interior, the President, and ultimately the United States Congress regarding how much, if any, of Apostle Islands National Lakeshore should be designated as wilderness.         Cultural Resources - Historic Structure and Cultural Landscape Reports (2011)         Natural Resources - Harvestable Species Plan (2014) (1.0mb pdf) - Harvestable Species Plan and EA (2014) (1.4mb pdf) - Apostle Islands Coastal Watershed Assessment (2007) (7.7mb pdf)         Visitor Use - Sand Island Campsite and Day-Use Plan/Environmental Assessment 2014 - Visitor Use Study (2004) (801kb pdf) - Visitor Use Report Summary (2004) (34kb pdf) - Accessibility Plan (2012) (7.8mb pdf)         Business/Economics/Budget - Apostle Islands National Lakeshore Business Plan (2001) (7.7mb pdf) - Apostle Islands - Pictured Rocks National Lakeshores Economic Study (2009) (2.6mb pdf) This report, by University of Montana Economist Thomas Michael Power, examines the regional economic context and the impact these protected areas have had on the regional economies since the establishment of these two Lake Superior national lakeshores.         Sustainability - Integrated Environmental Plan (updated annually). The park's IEP is a unique umbrella tool that organizes and optimizes environmental stewardship initiatives so greening can be accomplished efficiently and effectively.
